document_title: Chronic heart failure: Causes, symptoms and diagnosis
subsection_content:
Symptoms of chronic heart failure generally depend on the type of condition being experienced and its location, i.e. which ventricle is involved. (3)
The main symptom of left-sided heart failure is shortness of breath, which often gets worse with activity or when lying flat. Coughing may also appear. If the condition affects the right side of the heart, edema, a buildup of fluid that causes swelling of the legs and ankles, is the most common symptom.
Other symptoms, which can appear regardless of which side of the heart is affected, include:
Tired; Dizziness or lightheadedness; Nausea; Loss of appetite; Constipation; Feeling weak in the legs; Fast heartbeat, even at rest, or irregular heartbeat; Chest pain or angina
Doctors often classify a person's heart failure according to the severity of the symptoms being experienced. The New York Heart Association (NYHA) functional classification system is a commonly used classification system. Patients are arranged into 4 groups:
Group I: Physical activity not limited by symptoms.; Group II: Physical activity is slightly limited. Rest comfortably.; Group III: Physical activity is markedly limited. Rest comfortably.; Group IV: Discomfort when performing physical activity. Even at rest, symptoms may appear.
